Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(2) Summary

Loosely defined, APIs are mechanisms allowing two computer programs to communicate. Looking at APIs this way, virtually every organization has a lot of APIs in place already. This realization can be informative when starting the API journey or when it is time to start using APIs more strategically. API archaeology looks at the exiting landscape in organizations and allows to discover various evolutionary stages of APIs. Proto-APIs are communications mechanisms that have been put in place without using API approaches. Accidental APIs are APIs that came along as a side-effect of specific IT initiatives. Looking at the existing IT architecture can be helpful for identifying where strategic API investments are most valuable. These initial investments then become the foundation of an intentional journey towards APIs as a strategic enabler. This presentation discusses methods for analyzing the API status quo of an organization, and how this analysis can become the starting point for defining an API strategy and initiating an intentional API journey.

Proto-APIs

Proto-APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(7) APIs have been around forever…

  • What's old about APIs?
    • They have connected software components for decades
    • They used to be called protocols when APIs were just local
    • They (i.e., protocols) were used in decentralized architectures
  • What's new about APIs?
    • They remove the necessity to have centralized integration infrastructure
    • They're designed to be used by more than one consumer
    • Their main value is in aligning business agility with IT architecture
  • How to (a) identify potential and (b) unlock it by using APIs?


Proto-APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(8) File Transfer

  • One of the first integration methods
    • Based on a simple and widely shared abstraction (file systems and file formats)
    • Requires minimal alignment with while having obvious side-effects
  • Still widely used and for many scenarios a good-enough solution
    • Introduces long delays but still sufficient in many cases
    • Loose coupling in terms of infrastructure and runtime requirements
  • Challenged by modern UX expectations and goals
    • Impossible to build realtime-capable end-to-end digital experiences
    • Eventual consistency becomes the default operating model


Proto-APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(9) Data Integration

  • Putting machinery in place to help with file transfer
    • Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) as an integration pattern with a central data exchange hub
  • Typically targeted at underlying database systems
    • Synchronizes data by bypassing the application logic on top of the database
  • Having ETL in place makes it hard to change application logic
    • ETL processes duplicate logic and making any changes in the logic is costly and risky


Proto-APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(10) Application Integration

  • Synchronous ways how to connect applications
    • Some form of intermediary that establishes and manages connectivity
    • Bespoke integrations where each interconnection is created individually
  • Integration creates tight coupling and makes it hard to change components


Proto-APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(11) Proto-API Lessons

  1. Connecting two applications was deemed valuable enough to invest
  2. Is there a history of the connection holding up changes?
  3. What could happen if the Proto-API turned into a proper API?


API Journey

Outline (API Journey)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Proto-APIs [5]

API Journey Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(13) Start Small

  • Identify low-hanging fruit for quick success and feedback
    • API Archaeology is a good way to find candidates
  • Switch from building systems to cultivating ecosystems
    • Focus on constraints (what to do) over rules (how to do it)
    • Only govern when you must (autonomy) and not when you can (authority)
  • Start building a culture and a community
    • API Guidelines should reflect existing practices in an organization


API Journey Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(14) Design for Change

  • Ecosystem architecture and system architecture are distinct disciplines
    • APIs allow you to start building a landscape of API products
    • How to build API products is a different and distinct task
  • The role of ecosystem architecture is to support development teams
    • Constrain them as much as necessary but as little as possible
    • Cleanly separate constraints from how to implement them
    • Provide support for following constraints and testing for them
  • Always ask yourself how much effort it is to change course
    • Good ecosystem architecture scales over size and time and change frequency


API Journey Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(15) Cultivate the Landscape

  • Be clear on your vision and strategy
  • Start with small and focused effort and teams
  • Build up competencies and ways to share them across teams
  • Shift from centralized systems to decentralized ecosystems


API Journey Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(16) Growing the API Platform: Open Everything



API Journey Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(17) Why to add APIs

  1. Open Yourself: Unlock value in resources and capabilities
  2. Deliver Experiences through APIs: Treat new experiences as API first
  3. Be Open to Others: Add the platform angle to your business perspective


API Journey Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(18) Scaling is not Easy



Conclusions

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey

(20) Start Landscaping with a Purpose

  • Analyze the landscape to find high-potential API candidates
  • Avoid a waterfall model for your API journey
  • Start small and iterate and learn from the process
  • Design for change because change is the only constant
  • Build communities that cultivate and evolve practices


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Archaeology:
Guiding the API Journey
